quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Your brand name, nothing's going to be used more often or for longer than that name. Design will change, messaging will change, products will change, but that name is there.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A durable-priority mental model: invest in naming because it outlasts every other brand asset.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Humans do like to be comfortable. Part of our job here is to help people to give the confidence going bigger and being uncomfortable.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Practical guidance for naming decisions: expect discomfort and actively coach stakeholders through it.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If your team is comfortable with the name, chances are you don't have the name yet.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive heuristic that reframes early resistance as a signal you may be onto something strong.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We look for polarization. We look for tension in a team arguing about these things. Polarization is a sign of strength in the word.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A selection framework: treat polarized reactions as a positive indicator when evaluating candidate names.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Most clients, they come to a naming project absolutely believing with full confidence that they're going to know it when they see it, and the truth is it almost never happens.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Challenges the common “you’ll know it when you see it” belief and implies teams need a process, not gut feel.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point, your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and skim provisioning.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Highlights a predictable inflection point for SaaS teams: enterprise customer demands arrive inevitably, so planning for them early is practical.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A concise mental model for evaluating authorization systems: optimize for both scale and flexibility under complex requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a drop-in replacement for Auth0 and supports up to 1 million monthly active users for free.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A concrete adoption lever (low switching friction + generous free tier) that can materially change build-vs-buy decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Last year, 1.3% of the global GDP flowed through Stripe. That's over $1.4 trillion.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A striking scale datapoint that quantifies Stripe’s footprint and the operational reliability implied by that volume.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For example, Hertz boosted its online payment authorization rates by 4% after migrating to Stripe.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A specific outcome metric practitioners can use as a benchmark for payment stack migrations: authorization rate lift.

quotes.topic_title: Sonos: fighting for an uncomfortable name
quotes.text: And we argued about that because I said, "This is outside looking in, but I don't see you as an entertainment company. You make speakers that allow for the flow of entertainment through these things. And Sonos is about sound."
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Reframes category positioning by focusing on what the product enables (sound/flow) rather than the founders’ aspirational industry label (entertainment).

quotes.topic_title: Sonos: fighting for an uncomfortable name
quotes.text: But it had a particular quality. It's called a palindrome, which really means that you can flip it and it means the same thing. In the case of Sonos, you could also turn it upside down and it was essentially the same.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Shows a concrete naming heuristic: build in structural/visual properties that make a name distinctive and resilient across contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Sonos: fighting for an uncomfortable name
quotes.text: And I got on a plane, didn't even bill them for this, went back down to Santa Barbara and met with them again and said, "I really believe in this name and I think it's the right for you."
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Illustrates the practical reality that winning a great decision sometimes requires extra, unscoped effort to re-make the case in person.

quotes.topic_title: Sonos: fighting for an uncomfortable name
quotes.text: "You know? We're trying to name this for ourselves, and what we really should be doing is naming it for the marketplace and the customers. And I think Sonos now is the right name. And I felt really good about that."
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: optimize naming for customers/marketplace rather than founder identity or internal taste.

quotes.topic_title: Why you won’t know the right name
quotes.text: Most clients, and I can understand this, they come to a naming project absolutely believing, with full confidence, that they're going to know it when they see it. And the truth is, it almost never happens.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Reframes stakeholder expectations: you can’t rely on immediate recognition/intuition to select a strong name, so you need a process that accounts for delayed acceptance.

quotes.topic_title: Why you won’t know the right name
quotes.text: part of why clients don't like the bolder names, the more imaginative names that we present is they are looking for comfort. And that's the opposite that what you want to do.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Explains the core psychological failure mode in naming decisions—optimizing for comfort instead of differentiation and future advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Why you won’t know the right name
quotes.text: There is no power in comfort, not in the marketplace.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for evaluating options: if it feels too comfortable, it may be too generic to win in a competitive market.

quotes.topic_title: Why you won’t know the right name
quotes.text: This is why movies like Harry Potter or even novels like Jack London's Call of the Wild get rejected so many times. I think Harry Potter was rejected 16 or 18 times, and Jack London's book even more than that.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Concrete examples and a data point illustrating how novelty is often initially rejected because it doesn’t match prior success patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Why you won’t know the right name
quotes.text: our conversations always start with, "Talk to us about how you behave now and how you want to behave in the future," as opposed to, "Tell me about your positioning, tell me about your values, tell me about your mission."
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Offers a practical methodology shift: anchor naming in current/future behaviors (experience design) rather than static brand statements.

quotes.topic_title: Azure: avoiding “cloud” sameness with story
quotes.text: If you do that, you're going to be in an ocean of other cloud this, cloud that. And you have an opportunity as Microsoft here to really emerge as a leader in this.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A differentiation warning: descriptor-based naming (“cloud ___”) collapses you into sameness, while distinctiveness can signal leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Azure: avoiding “cloud” sameness with story
quotes.text: So, we really presented it based on its linguistic qualities. It's a noisy word, that Z in there. It starts with an A, and it ends in a nice smooth flow. So, we really strive to do create names that are balanced. And in a very busy competitive world, having a strong signal, which is generated by noise is a good thing.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A practical naming framework: evaluate “linguistic qualities” (signal/noise, phonetics, balance) to stand out in crowded markets.

quotes.topic_title: Azure: avoiding “cloud” sameness with story
quotes.text: You don't want to make a statement here. You want to start a story.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A counterintuitive branding principle: names should create narrative runway rather than merely describe what the product is.

quotes.topic_title: Azure: avoiding “cloud” sameness with story
quotes.text: And Azure is going to behave differently in the marketplace than Cloud Pro, which is I think one of the names that we presented to them on the other site at their request.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A concrete example contrasting a distinctive brandable name (“Azure”) with a generic descriptor (“Cloud Pro”) to illustrate market impact.

quotes.topic_title: How great names create cumulative advantage
quotes.text: Your brand name, whether it's a product name or a company name, nothing's going to be used more often or for longer than that name. Design will change, messaging will change, products will change, but that name is there.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A durable-asset framing: the name outlasts other brand elements, so it compounds in importance over time.

quotes.topic_title: How great names create cumulative advantage
quotes.text: So, I like to talk about this idea of cumulative advantage. Over time, as people buy more and more of the product, they see it more often, that their bond between you and that brand, or them and the brand I should say, becomes stronger and stronger. So you want that name to stick in their mind to be distinctive, because distinctiveness is what creates that cumulative advantage.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Introduces a compounding mental model for naming: distinctiveness strengthens memory and attachment with repeated exposure.

quotes.topic_title: How great names create cumulative advantage
quotes.text: The second thing is this notion of what I call asymmetric advantage. It makes perfect sense, and most clients agree with this when we say this is that even before you launch this brand, why not start with an advantage in the marketplace?
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A pre-launch strategy principle: naming can create an immediate edge before product adoption or marketing spend.

quotes.topic_title: How great names create cumulative advantage
quotes.text: And you won't get an advantage if you're descriptive. If you are Cloud Pro and there's 10 other cloud services, you're not going to stand out in the marketplace.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Actionable guidance against descriptive names, illustrated with a concrete example of how sameness kills differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: How great names create cumulative advantage
quotes.text: Our mission is to create the right name for clients, because the right name does deliver asymmetric advantage and cumulative advantage for you. And that, for us, has almost unlimited value.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A succinct synthesis of the two-part framework (asymmetric + cumulative advantage) and why it matters economically.

quotes.topic_title: Lexicon’s three-step naming process overview
quotes.text: Well, our process is real. I break it down in three steps. First, we have to identify, then we invent, and then we implement. It's just three things. It's not rocket science, but it's a combination of creativity and discipline.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable 3-step framework that turns naming from “charisma” into an operational process teams can run.

quotes.topic_title: Lexicon’s three-step naming process overview
quotes.text: In the first section of identify, it's really trying to find out from the client, let's talk about behavior. So, how are you behaving now and how do you want to behave in the future? That behavior is bidirectional.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Reframes early naming discovery around desired behaviors/experience (and the two-way relationship between brand and market), not just features or positioning statements.

quotes.topic_title: Lexicon’s three-step naming process overview
quotes.text: Because we have to be distinctive. If a brand name isn't distinctive, you lose. Then, you're imitating. And that's a form of suicide.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable rule that pushes practitioners to map the competitive language landscape and avoid “me-too” naming.

quotes.topic_title: Lexicon’s three-step naming process overview
quotes.text: And we don't use... This will be contrary. We don't use large brainstorming sections. I did. When I first started the company, I used freelancers, I used large brainstorming groups. And along the way through some analysis, we really discovered that that was not really working for us. That actually, the names were coming from employees and from small groups.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Counterintuitive process insight: smaller teams outperform big brainstorms for generating strong names.

quotes.topic_title: Lexicon’s three-step naming process overview
quotes.text: One team knows everything about the project but the other teams don't. If we're working for Microsoft, the second team thinks they're working for Apple. I mean, they know it's disguised. We're not keeping this from anyone. And then the third team, we take it out of computers, and they might be naming a bicycle or a car or something like that.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A practical creativity technique—use disguised briefs and cross-domain prompts to unlock more original naming directions.

quotes.topic_title: Who makes great namers and why brainstorms fail
quotes.text: So, the fundamental quality is they're going to be curious and they're going to be hardworking. This is... And hopefully... And this is hard to screen for, but lower egos.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Defines the core hiring profile for great namers: curiosity, work ethic, and low ego.

quotes.topic_title: Who makes great namers and why brainstorms fail
quotes.text: Here, I can't just sit down and say, "Okay, we're naming a new car here. And so, I'm going to generate 100 names and you generate 100 names, and something will fall out." Those names will not... There's not enough in that list to clear through our screens. Of legal screens, our linguistic screens.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Challenges the common brainstorm/volume assumption by explaining why typical output won’t survive real-world screening.

quotes.topic_title: Who makes great namers and why brainstorms fail
quotes.text: So, we're looking for people who can churn out a lot of work. And when that's rejected, they just keep going. So, we look for tenacious people.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Actionable selection criterion: prioritize high-output resilience over “one brilliant idea.”

quotes.topic_title: Who makes great namers and why brainstorms fail
quotes.text: So, it's relatively easy for anyone that works here to develop a list of 2 or 300 names over a 3 or 4-day period.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Provides a concrete throughput benchmark for name generation when supported by tools and process.

quotes.topic_title: Who makes great namers and why brainstorms fail
quotes.text: More who are writers from newspaper reporters because they have to work fast. Their stories get rejected. People who might have written a novel.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Gives a practical sourcing heuristic: recruit from roles trained for speed, rejection, and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Windsurf case study and compound-name multipliers
quotes.text: So our rule here is if there's something that is intangible like that, we have to make it tangible.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A practical naming heuristic: when the product is abstract, force the team to translate it into tangible metaphors or contexts to generate better names.

quotes.topic_title: Windsurf case study and compound-name multipliers
quotes.text: And sometimes we do that not by giving a team, sometimes it's an individual, the assignment to create ideas for the brand itself, but to just dive into a particular context.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A method shift: instead of brainstorming names directly, assign exploration of a context to unlock more original naming territory.

quotes.topic_title: Windsurf case study and compound-name multipliers
quotes.text: We know from the research we've invested in that compounds like Powerbook or Facebook are multipliers of associations because there's wind and there's circles around that, and then there's surf images around that. So 1 + 1 = 3, right?
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why compound names can outperform single words by multiplying imagery and associations.

quotes.topic_title: Windsurf case study and compound-name multipliers
quotes.text: It's interesting that when we present compounds to clients, we often get the comment, "Well, it's a little bit long and it's a compound. I'd rather have a shorter single word."
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about stakeholder bias toward short names, setting up the case for compounds despite initial resistance.

quotes.topic_title: Windsurf case study and compound-name multipliers
quotes.text: But we explained to them about the multiplier effect of compounds. We showed them imagery that they could use. I mean, it's simple to execute on something like that.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Actionable persuasion tactic: use the compound “multiplier effect” plus concrete imagery to help teams commit and execute on a longer, image-rich name.

quotes.topic_title: Naming AI products: engineers, speed, and trust
quotes.text: First off, we are working mostly with engineers, and engineers who haven't delved into the world of creativity and necessarily marketing. And that's their strength. And what we have to do is we have to balance their strength with our strength.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A practical collaboration model: treat engineering and marketing/creative as complementary strengths that must be intentionally balanced in naming decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Naming AI products: engineers, speed, and trust
quotes.text: Secondly, this is the fastest moving progressing category I have ever experienced. And I have that perspective, right? I went through the early days of the internet and the World Wide Web, and that was moving pretty fast. But the internet compared to this looks like a daycare school or something like that. We're challenged by just keeping up with developments.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A counterintuitive benchmark for practitioners: AI naming/positioning must assume extreme velocity—faster than the early internet—so processes must be built for rapid iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Naming AI products: engineers, speed, and trust
quotes.text: Third thing, and this is the creative challenge here, is that engineers come to us wanting more sophisticated names where they are likely to end up with another Codium or an Anduril or an Anthropic.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A repeatable pattern to watch for: engineer-led naming tends toward “coded” sophistication, which can produce a crowded, lookalike naming landscape.

quotes.topic_title: Naming AI products: engineers, speed, and trust
quotes.text: And we did a series of research. I probably invested $20,000 or so. And we interviewed consumers in Europe, South Korea, just picked out one country in Asia, and in America, and developers in those three. And they really have different views. Developers are all totally positive on it.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A concrete methodology and data point: spend to research both consumers and developers across regions because their attitudes toward AI diverge sharply.

quotes.topic_title: Naming AI products: engineers, speed, and trust
quotes.text: So Codium is an example where we said, "We think what you're doing needs to be much more tangible, and something that people can grab onto, and much more natural as opposed to a Codium."
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Actionable naming guidance for skeptical markets: choose tangible, natural names that people can “grab onto” rather than abstract, coded-sounding ones.

quotes.topic_title: When to change a company or product name
quotes.text: And the larger you are and the more customer base you have, it becomes a significant project. So the first thing is you have to make an argument that it's worth the change. That we're going to be better off by changing our name.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A practical decision rule: treat renaming as a high-cost project and require a clear ROI case before proceeding.

quotes.topic_title: When to change a company or product name
quotes.text: Startups get going early, they get into Y Combinator or something like that, they're raising money. And they just need a name.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Highlights a common early-stage trigger for renaming: placeholder names chosen under fundraising/time pressure.

quotes.topic_title: When to change a company or product name
quotes.text: And that is the absolute expression I hear from when a startup calls and says, "We want to change your name. We started off a year and a half ago. We just needed a name for the documents, and so we chose X."
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A memorable, real-world pattern you can use to diagnose whether your current name is a temporary artifact rather than a durable brand.

quotes.topic_title: When to change a company or product name
quotes.text: Number two is the company actually has pivoted. And so, the name that they have no longer really reflects who they are or who they're becoming, and which makes that name ineffective.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A clear framework trigger: if the name no longer matches the company’s present/future identity, it stops doing its job.

quotes.topic_title: When to change a company or product name
quotes.text: And the third is that a company has merged and it is time now to create a new start and reflect to the marketplace that we're... We're new now, maybe bigger, but certainly we have more capabilities and we want you to know about it.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Positions renaming post-merger as a market signal to communicate a reset and expanded capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've rebuilt it from the ground up with AI.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Highlights a methodology shift—re-architecting a product end-to-end around AI rather than bolting AI onto an existing workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: FileFeeds 2.0 allows non-technical teams to automate the process of transforming CSV in Excel files with just a simple prompt.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Actionable product principle: move complex data transformation work from engineers to non-technical users via prompt-driven automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've heard so many horror stories of outages from even just a single bad record in transactions, employee files, purchase orders, you name it.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Concrete cautionary example that a single malformed row can cascade into system outages across critical business data flows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Debugging these issues is often like finding a needle in a haystack.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for why reactive data cleanup is costly—errors are hard to locate once they enter downstream systems.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: OneSchema stops any bad data from entering your system and automatically validates your files, generating error reports with the exact issues in all bad files.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Practical approach: prevent and validate at ingestion, and produce precise error reporting to reduce time-to-fix.

quotes.topic_title: Linguists as evaluators and cultural risk filters
quotes.text: But the preponderance of their work in our linguistic network is to evaluate names. Not only just does it mean something negative or positive, but are there cultural implications to it? Political implications? Or even things that a natural disaster that would've happened somewhere that no one here would know about.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A practical evaluation framework: linguistic review should include cultural, political, and local-history risk—not just literal meaning.

quotes.topic_title: Linguists as evaluators and cultural risk filters
quotes.text: Someone that speaks Italian very well here, say at Berkeley University, but has lived here for 20 years, wouldn't know about that.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that fluency (even expert-level) doesn’t equal current local cultural awareness—use in-market checks.

quotes.topic_title: Linguists as evaluators and cultural risk filters
quotes.text: And we don't want anything linguistically that would slow our clients down. And so, that's why we've invested in building this network.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Clear business rationale: treat linguistic/cultural screening as a speed and risk-reduction investment for launches.

quotes.topic_title: Linguists as evaluators and cultural risk filters
quotes.text: I would say it happens every third or fourth project we'll find something that we will eliminate and never show the client.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Concrete frequency data point showing how often name candidates fail cultural/linguistic risk filters in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Sound symbolism: what letters feel like
quotes.text: V, from our research that we've done, is the most alive and vibrant sound in the English alphabet.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A concrete, research-backed example of sound symbolism practitioners can use when choosing brand/product names.

quotes.topic_title: Sound symbolism: what letters feel like
quotes.text: B, the sound of the letter B is one of the most reliable sounds in the English alphabet.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A practical naming heuristic: certain phonemes can reliably cue desired brand attributes like trustworthiness.

quotes.topic_title: Sound symbolism: what letters feel like
quotes.text: And all of a sudden, people at least lean forward to consider it as opposed to rejecting it too fast.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that small phonetic/structural choices can prevent premature rejection of novel names.

quotes.topic_title: Sound symbolism: what letters feel like
quotes.text: By the way, that's known as processing fluency, which is when you think about how the brain processes information.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Introduces a useful cognitive-science framework for evaluating whether a name will be easy to understand and remember.

quotes.topic_title: Sound symbolism: what letters feel like
quotes.text: Names that are complicated, it's a liability.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for practitioners: complexity in naming creates friction and should be avoided.

quotes.topic_title: Implementation: prototypes, research, and internal buy-in
quotes.text: But for us, implement is helping the client team, if they choose, for us to help them with the presentations as it goes up the chain. To help them write a longer rationale for why these names, if they're presenting three names to the president of their company or the CMO, why these names make a lot of sense, and to help them develop what we call prototypes.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Implementation is framed as enabling internal buy-in with executive-ready rationales and tangible prototypes, not just delivering options.

quotes.topic_title: Implementation: prototypes, research, and internal buy-in
quotes.text: We'll put the name on a baseball cap, on a T-shirt. We'll put the name in a mock-up ad in the Wall Street Journal. Something's very positive. Because of Procter & Gamble's new blank product. P&G shares, they gain 10% this year. So that executives can see that the lift that that name can have.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A concrete prototyping tactic: simulate real-world brand presence to help decision-makers feel the upside.

quotes.topic_title: Implementation: prototypes, research, and internal buy-in
quotes.text: And that's the most important thing in research, not is the name popular, are they comfortable with it, does it fit to concept. If you're asking people is this fit to concept, you are inevitably always going to get a descriptive name.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: Counterintuitive research guidance: avoid “fit to concept” questions because they bias outcomes toward safe, descriptive naming.

quotes.topic_title: Implementation: prototypes, research, and internal buy-in
quotes.text: We try in a very diplomatic way to say, "This has nothing, really, in the end to do with your boss. It has to do with the marketplace."
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A reframing tool for internal politics: anchor decisions on market success rather than a manager’s personal taste.

quotes.topic_title: Implementation: prototypes, research, and internal buy-in
quotes.text: But if you're just taking names up to a manager and saying, "What do you think?" There's a different outcome offered.
quotes.speaker: David Placek
quotes.context: A practical buy-in lesson: present as an execution-ready recommendation, not an open-ended request for opinion.
